fields.description:
I would be nice if you could pull the xml view from a project employing an existing filter.  Right now there is a way to  get saved filters using Soap, and it would be useful if we could employ a filter and retrieve tasks using it.  Perhaps like this:

XMLString = getRssFeed(token, projectId, filterId)

I would like to suggest this feature.
fields.summary: Soap: get xml view of issues in a project

fields.description:
I'm using soap to populate Jira.   Working with custom fields is difficult because you have to dig out the custom field ID from deep in the administration of Jira.  Since the Soap API already has methods such as getPriorities and getIssueTypes, it would make sense to have a similar method such as:

getCustomFields(token, projKey)

which would return an array of the existing custom fields.   I would like to suggest this feature.
fields.summary: Soap: getCustomFields()

fields.description: I had a search with several pages of issues (JIRA's 3.2 bug fix list I think). I then opened a new window to view my reported issues. Now, I know that JIRA does not support multiple searches in the same browser since it is cookie based, so I didn't expect my original search to still be valid. But when I went back to the first search and pressed "Next" (page), JIRA told me I was  "Displaying issues 51 to 17 of 17 matching issues." The problem being the starting number is 51 which was from the first search and the ending number being from the second search.

TIA

fields.description:
Lucene is not able to index fields that are earlier than 1st January 1970. When a date such as this is entered as a due date or a custom field of type date, the value cannot be indexed, and the following sort of errors are logged when issues are indexed:
2005-02-11 21:14:08,390 WARN [jira.issue.index.AbstractDocument] Unable to index field 'duedate' from FMGP-71 with value: 0005-01-28 00:00:00.0 

As most users do not need to record dates before 1st Jan 1970, and usually make a mistake when entering a date, we need to create an integrity checker that finds these dates and corrects them. Note that most of the time the problem surfaced because users specified dates using 2 digits for years, e.g. 05, instead of 2005, and the default date mask needed a 4 year digit. Since JIRA 3.1 the default date mask has been changed to expect 2 digit year and the problem should not appear too often.

Old issues still need to be fixed.

An alternive for now is to write an SQL script that fixes these dates in the database, or export data to XML, correct it an reimport.
fields.summary: Create an integrity check that validates dates so that they can be indexed.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6851].
  {panel}


In the custom field configuration context, it is not possible to  choose a project if it has already been associated to another configuration context of the same custom field. For instance, it is not possible to make the following associations:

Task, project1, configuration context 1
Task, project2, configuration context 2
Bug, project1, configuration context 3
Bug, project2, configuration context 4
fields.summary: Allow more than one custom field context to be associated with the same project but different issue types

1.1

fields.description:
Now that all issue constants (Issue Types, Resolutions, Priorities and Statues) can be associated with a translation set, as suggested by Arne Schirmacher, it would be useful to add default translation sets for each constant for each available locale.

Hence, for example, when users navigate to the German translation section for issue types, the default German translations for Bug, New Feature, Task and Improvement would already be listed.
fields.summary: Add default translation sets for issue constant translations.

fields.description:
It would be very useful if one could configure which groups filters can be shared with, and which groups not.

The users at my company have a tendancy to share filters with too big a group - and I would like to be able to disallow sharing filters with this , and other, groups. Since our JIRA instance is used by multiple project-teams, people start complaining when a lot of shared filters are visible to them that they personally have no use for. It clutters their dashboard.

And of course I have tried educating the users, but no luck there! Also, I've split the groups in groups for "filtering" and groups for permission-control. Both are evident from the name, but still no luck getting the users to abide :-)

And I already hacked it so a users __must__ select a group to share with - i.e. share with all is not shown (commented out in the code).

(I'm not a Java wizard, but if someone can point out - for example - how (and where) I can check the start of the name of a group a users wishes to share a filter with, and only allow the share if the start matches a specific string, I'll hack that in.)
fields.summary: Limit which groups filters can shared with

fields.description: Perhaps you could reuse the tree view  from confluence. Advantages: You could define more sublevels and its clearer than cascading select
fields.summary: Provide a Tree View Customfield

- components
- affects Version/s

fields.description:
Currently if you want to implement Issue, it is quite difficult, as you need to implement all the 'set' methods.

We should distinguish between times when you want a MutableIssue, and times when you just want one for viewing.

fields.description:
Importing users through CSV map names as firstnamelastname

We should allow for other common formats like first letter of first name + last name. So John Smith becomes jsmith.

There will certainly be problems when we have "James Smith", but it will be up to the user to pre-prepare the import file in such circumstances (creating lookup columns etc)
fields.summary: Importing users through CSV only map names as firstnamelastname

Example:

Group 1 : 3--------------------------------------------- 10%
Group 2 : 50 ---------------------------------------------------------- 20%

fields.description:
Just received a mail with Philips komment on JRA-6798. The heading looks like this:

"[JIRA] Kommentiert: (JRA-6798) Issue Constant Translations - much is missing".

What happened here? "Commented" got  translated to "Kommentiert" (german). Must be because Philip uses the german locale?
fields.summary: Wrong e-mail header

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6798].
  {panel}

Original description:

From the JIRA 3.2 Beta Release Notes:
"Continuing our commitment to a fully internationalisable issue manager, JIRA 3.2 provides the ability to translate all issue settings - i.e. Priorities, Statuses, Issue Types and Resolutions. This allows for even more complete translations to present JIRA to each user in their own chosen language."

I still miss being able to translate the following settings before JIRA is fully internationalisable. 

1. Project Categories
2. Issue linking
3. Sub-Task Types
4. Workflows (i know i can make a new workflow in a second language, but when two persons with two different languages uses the same project, the workflow will only be presented in one of the languages) and their transitions.
5. Custom Fields (same problem as with workflows)
6. Security Levels
7. Field Sceen Tabs
8. Field descriptions

In other words: anything user configurable that is shown to the users.

As long as this is missing, it still gives no sense to use JIRA in a multilanguage environment. My setup is in danish. A person speaking only english will not be able to use it, since the workflow, the security levels and so on gives no meaning to him.

Disclaimer: i haven't installed 3.2 yet, so if any of the above settings actually IS translatable, please excuse me for not being up-to-date.

Regards,
Lars
fields.summary: Allow admins to translate items configurable in the administration section

fields.description:
Under certain conditions, connections are leaked:

- Tomcat (not certain if we need this)
- Oracle (with tryclob...) or MSSQL
- Try running quicksearch with a key that isn't found - this will search through the change history
- Because Oracle (and MSSQL presumably) can't do exact text match queries in CLOBs (though 'like' queries work), and exception is thrown
- This exception propagates up to JIRA code.  However, ofbiz doesn't close the connection.
- If you do this enough times (more than number of connections in DB pool - 8 in Tomcat's commons-dbcp) then you run out of connections, and JIRA appears to hang.
fields.summary: Connection leak when database error occurs causes JIRA to eventually hang

fields.description:

From JRA-6771:
For example, all my imports are bugs so I should be able to specify that in the import rather than update the csv to include an extra column for the issue type.

fields.description:
The ony way you can reduce a prior work log entry is to enter another negative one. You can enter a negative work time such as -30 and the system will accept it, and it is correctly subtracted from the total work effort. (I could only enter a negative # of minutes. -1d is not accepted by the system, but -480 is.) In any case, the negative entry is not shown in the work log entry.

In addition, the system will allow a negative net work effort. 

If the entry of negative time is disallowed in a future release, will there be a valid way to back out work estimates?
fields.summary: Can enter negative work time. Not shown in work log.

fields.summary: # caracter in the summary field

fields.description:
One of my users has found that due dates are being inconsistently displayed.  I suspect we've just got a configuration problem of some kind, but I'm not sure.  When I open a single issue and click "Edit this issue" then the due date shows up as "05/27/05" (we set the date format to typical US notation earlier, through some Java property that you told me about).  However, when I look at the main view of the issue, the date line says

Created: Thursday 11:40 AM   Updated: Monday 01:15 PM   Due: 01/27/05

And when I view the issue along with others in Issue Navigator, it also says the due date is "01/27/05".

5/27/05 is the real due date, but it's getting shown as 01/27/05 in these other two views.

Any ideas what might be wrong?
fields.summary: due dates are inconsistent

fields.description:
When an issue has a summary "java.lang.NullPointerException"
a search on "NullPointerException" will yield no results.

This also limits searching on method names where fully qualified names were entered in the issue.

fields.description: Some people wish to do unusual things with listeners, like creating users in a parallel database when users are created in JIRA.  This requires access to all details (username, email, password) in the listener.  Unfortunately JIRA 3.1.x and below don't pass any of this information in the listener's Map.
fields.summary: Pass all details (including password) in USER_CREATED and USER_FORGOTPASSWORD events.

fields.description:
Situation:

Currently we are using the Scrum Process and using jira to manage our product backlog.  The only think missing is the ability to use Jira to create a relative priority for each issue so that a Product Manager can go into Jira and order the product backlog into a definite list of priority.

Solution:

Allow certain users to prioritize issues in Jira relative to one another, and allow users to sort by this priority in search results.
fields.summary: Allow for relative ranking of Jira Issues

fields.description:
Include attached translations file for 3.2.

A big shout out to YB Chen for supplying this.
fields.summary: Include Traditional Chinese translation

Specifically I have created a new issue type and I would like to remove the fields "Affects Version/s", "Fix Version/s", "Component/s" and "Environment" from this type.

fields.description:
We are currently experiencing a big problem in Jira.

This results in the big problem that issues disappear in lists (the lists that show users the issues they have assigned.
It seems that the problem occur in the folliwing circumstances:

- When issues are reassigned a system error occurs and no email-notifications are sent. AND issues does not appear in any lists and can not be found in searches 
-- but if one remembers the exact issue ID they can be found, by directly accessing their respective URL's
- when comments are made on issues notifications are sent, but issues does not appear in any lists and can not be found in searches 

This is of course a huge problem, and we do not know how to solve :-(
Hope that you have a suggestion for us! :-)
fields.summary: Issues does not appear in liste (after reassign and assign)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6772].
  {panel}

Currently, if  you want to use a Jira RSS feed in an RSS aggregator, you have to copy the URL and manually add os_username=pol&os_password=pot.
This is a bit of a PITA. Most users dont know this os_incantation.

Also, for the {jiraissues} macro in Confluence, you are forced to put the username/password in clear text.

What I would like to see is something like Fisheye's RSS support. Fisheye generates a url with a security token - which can be used for that URL only. The security tokens are stored against a user - so its possible for a user to nuke all their pre-authenticated tokens.
fields.summary: Generate authenticated token for RSS url

java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: PermissionType passed to this function must a global permission, 23 is not

As i do not have admin or project admin rights i was expecting to get a permission exception.  The error message is also a bit cryptic.  I think it may be missing a 'be'.  It would also be nice if it used the permission name instead of the id.
fields.summary: Unexpected exceptions from Scheme Services

fields.description:
It would be useful to develop a custom field that integrates with Confluence.  The custom field would allow a user to select a Confluence page (and in the future - multiple pages), from one or more confluence instances.

In the setup for the field - you can select which Confluence instances you want to integrate with, and assign them a unique id (eg. cac = http://confluence.atlassian.com/).  Then if you use a text area - you can specify 'Confluence instance / space name / page name' 

eg:   'cac/DOC/Documentation+Home'

JIRA would then save the 'id' of that page in the JIRA database.

I expect that most users would want to search for pages - we would need a popup (using the webwork plugin) that would enable users to search the confluence instance for the page that they want to link to.  This would be using the Confluence remote API.

We also need to be able to search for pages that are linked to a particular confluence page.  This would enable a macro to be written in JIRA that allows you to show all the JIRA issues that are linked to a particular Confluence page. (how cool would that be for feature requests!).

A longer term solution would be if you can search across both instances!
fields.summary: Custom field that links with Confluence page

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6754].
  {panel}

Sometimes it is hard to contact the correct people in a company regarding the renewal of JIRA maintenance.  Sometimes they have moved position, or left the company, or are otherwise hard to get a hold of.

From within JIRA, we know who the system administrators are.  We should email these people regarding the renewal of their JIRA maintenance, from within JIRA.

We should email them twice - once 3 months out, and then another 1 month out.  We should create a documentation page explaining why they got the email.

This will enable people to be better informed that the maintenance is about to end, and allow people more time to take advantage of any special pricing.

The downside is that we could potentially spam a lot of people.  If the admin list is more than 20 people, we should probably not email anyone (to avoid spamming ppl).

As the email content will ship with JIRA - we must ensure that the copy does not contain any information which may evolve over time (such as licensing or pricing information).  The email should probably inform the user that the maintenance is ending, and point them to an online page.

The option to send reminder emails should be configurable from the administration system (default to on).  We should also record what emails were sent to whom, to prevent any system errors turning into a mail loop.
fields.summary: Email admins about license renewal (from within JIRA)

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Server*. Using *JIRA Cloud*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JRACLOUD-6753].
  {panel}

Currently, if there is a security advisory, or if there is an upgrade available, there is not a simple way to inform JIRA administrators.

We should design a portlet & admin page that sends details from the local instance to Atlassian, and a page at Atlassian that informs users of the current updates available / pertinent to their system.

This would be done by a simple HMTL 'get' request to the remote Atlassian box, and the Atlassian box can return a small amount of HTML that is then rendered on the client.

As we cannot guarantee the connectivity, the download will need to happen as a service.  We should also set the timeout on the HTTP request to something sensible (like 10-15 seconds).

We need to work out which information to send to Atlassian.  I think initially we should send:
- version number (build number)
- which edition (standard / pro / ent)

I'm not sure if we should send the license details.  On one hand - it would be useful to know when the license ends so that we can send information about which versions are available for upgrade.  On the other hand, it may be a privacy issue (potentially).

Other information which you can send (in the future):
- installed plugins

The information should be displayed as a portlet (available only to admins), and also as a screen in the administration section.

Perhaps for important advisories we should display information as a banner across the top of the administration screen?  If so - we would need a way of indicating that in the response (perhaps we need to use XML instead?).
fields.summary: Create 'remote' portlet / admin screen, which contacts Atlassian for administration information
Turn system operations into system fields

fields.description:
Currently the different views of an issue are done through JSP.

We should make view of an issue pluggable so that we can use velocity (through the plugin system).

We should also allow for other content types to be created (eg application/pdf for a PDF version of an issue).

Currently the XML version is linked up the top - in the future, other versions would be linked (with the default view being the one displayed normally).

One other implication is to use the same (similar) view technology for the differing views on the issue navigator.  You could reuse the 'full content view' (which should be the printable view of an issue repeated), as well as the XML view.  A CSV view may also be useful, although less useful on an individual issue.
fields.summary: Turn HTML / XML / Excel / PDF versions of an issue into plugins
